docs.lead_paragraph: After a visit to the birthplace of the women's suffrage movement, Representative Rick A. Lazio challenged Hillary Rodham Clinton on one of her core issues, women's health care, igniting a battle over which candidate had done more about breast cancer prevention. Mr. Lazio, the Republican Senate candidate, has said all along that he would court constituencies and speak on issues not normally identified with Republicans, but his attack today showed an aggressive attempt to seize an issue Mrs. Clinton has promoted. It also illustrated the opportunity his strategists see to attract women voters, some of whom, according to recent polls, were not backing Mrs. Clinton as strongly as had been expected.

headline.main: Lazio Faults Mrs. Clinton For Record In Health Care

docs.abstract: Rep Rick A Lazio, campaigning for Senate, visits Women's Rights National Historic Park, Seneca Falls, NY, and challenges Hillary Rodham Clinton on one of her key issues; holds she has record of undermining women's health, falling short on advocating insurance coverage for mammograms for early breast cancer detection; Clinton's staff disputes Lazio; notes National Breast Cancer Coalition recently honored her (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When he accepted the Republican presidential nomination in Philadelphia two weeks ago, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas skipped lightly over a few issues -- taxes, Social Security, education, nuclear weapons -- and then got to his topic sentence: ''We must usher in an era of responsibility.'' In Los Angeles on Thursday night, Vice President Al Gore took the opposite approach. Declaring that ''the presidency is more than a popularity contest,'' he said, ''I am here to talk seriously about the issues.''
docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush take starkly different positions on a host of issues, the most important being how the government will use the budget surplus over the next decade; Gore highlighted those differences in his acceptance speech, while Bush skipped lightly over them in his, focusing instead on the need for a new era of responsibility (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Progress Is Seen in Talks As Phone Strike Continues Negotiators for more than 86,000 striking telephone workers and Verizon Communications reached tentative agreement on several critical issues, but an overall settlement to the 13-day walkout remained bogged down in the details. Verizon agreed to move less than 1 percent of its employees each year to other places, and it broadened an agreement to organize employees of Verizon's wireless division, people close to the talks said. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Heartened by a federal court victory in Philadelphia last week in the managed care wars, lawyers for several major health insurance companies are seeking to consolidate a host of lawsuits accusing managed care companies of misleading customers. They also hope to transfer the suits from Miami to Philadelphia. The federal district judge who is hearing arguments in the cases in Miami said Thursday that he would rule shortly on whether to suspend action there while requests to move the suits are decided.

headline.main: Managed Care Companies Seek to Build on a Legal Victory

docs.abstract: Managed care companies seek to consolidate lawsuits accusing them of misleading customers and hope to transfer suits from Miami to Philadelphia, where a federal appeals court has ruled that US Healthcare unit of Aetna did not violate racketeering laws when it advertised that it was providing quality medical care even as it was encouraging cost-cutting by doctors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After four days of giving a national television audience a generally positive look at itself and its candidates, the Democratic Party turned today to how to attack the Republicans and Gov. George W. Bush on a variety of issues, with a heavy emphasis on abortion. At a raucously enthusiastic meeting of the Democratic National Committee, the party's general chairman, Edward G. Rendell, said, ''This was a nice, upbeat convention, and it was the right thing to do.''

headline.main: Setting Aside Friendly Face, Democrats Plot an Attack

docs.abstract: Democratic Party devises an offensive against Republicans and Gov George W Bush after a national convention in which it gave nation a generally positive look at itself and its candidates; messages on how to attack Republicans are interspersed with instructions to work hard and unite (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman took to the Mississippi today, weaving the river's epic symbolism into a populist challenge against the political influence of oil corporations, health maintenance organizations and drug companies. Before boarding the Mark Twain riverboat for a four-day, 390-mile journey down the Mississippi, Mr. Gore stood at the bank here and promised, as he had done last night in accepting the Democratic presidential nomination in Los Angeles, to make campaign finance reform his first legislative priority.

headline.main: Gore and Lieberman Take Their Message to the Banks of the Mississippi

docs.snippet: Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman took to the Mississippi today, weaving the river's epic symbolism into a populist challenge against the political influence of oil corporations, health maintenance organizations and drug...

docs.lead_paragraph: Reliance Group Holdings, the New York insurer controlled by the financier Saul P. Steinberg, agreed in principle yesterday to sell its accident and health business to a unit of the Aon Corporation. The sale, for a price still to be negotiated, continues the dismantling of Reliance, which has been struggling with widening losses. The company has said it will probably not be able to repay $735.1 million of debt due at the end of the month and may seek bankruptcy protection. Aon, the world's second-largest insurance brokerage company, said its Combined Insurance Company of America unit had agreed to assume virtually all of Reliance's accident and health policies as of Aug. 1.

headline.main: AON IS BUYING ACCIDENT AND HEALTH UNIT FROM RELIANCE

docs.abstract: Reliance Group Holdings, controlled by financier Saul P Steinberg, sells its accident and health business to unit of Aon Corp; sale price is still to be negotiated (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A deputy no more, Vice President Al Gore made his debut as the Democratic presidential nominee tonight with a vow to work for all Americans, ''especially those who need a voice, those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind.'' Speaking to the Democratic National Convention that nominated him on Wednesday night and to the nation beyond, Mr. Gore said, ''I stand here tonight as my own man'' -- a clear rejoinder to the Republicans who have sought to picture him as a cut-rate version of President Clinton. [Transcript, Page A21-22.]

headline.main: GORE, IN DEBUT AS A PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE, SAYS 'I STAND HERE TONIGHT AS MY OWN MAN'

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore makes his debut as Democratic presidential nominee with vow to work for all Americans; speaking to Democratic National Convention and the nation beyond, Gore distances himself from Pres Clinton, saying 'I stand here tonight as my own man'; lays groundwork for a fall campaign in which he will identify himself as friend of the little guy and Gov George Bush as candidate of the rich, powerful and influential; Gore lays out his position on range of issues in speech with few rhetorical flourishes or unexpected policy departures; promises to enact tax reforms targeting working families, preserve abortion rights, oppose school vouchers and support affirmative action; says comprehensive campaign spending reform bill will be his first order of business if elected; photo (M)
